All car passengers must wear seat belt

Staff Reporter
Panaji

Goa police will penalise four-wheeler drivers if any passenger travelling in the car is not wearing a seat belt. Fine for not wearing a seat belt is `1,000.

A senior police officer said that by law it is mandatory for passengers travelling in a car to wear a seat belt. However, the rule was relaxed for passengers seated in the rear.

Earlier this month, Nitin Gadkari, the Union Minister for Road Transport and Highways, had stressed on the importance of wearing seat belts and had said that rear seat passengers not wearing a seat belt would be penalised.

The move was in view of the fatal accident that occurred recently in Palghar district of Maharashtra that took the life of former chairperson of Tata Sons Cyrus Mistry and another co-passenger on September 4. They were reportedly not wearing seat belts.

Directions have been issued by the Centre on implementing the safety seat belt rule. Police said that safety belts are essential in ensuring safety of occupants of vehicles and as per the Motor Vehicle Act, it is mandatory to use safety belts.

Police said that whoever drives a motor vehicle without wearing a seat belt or carries passengers not wearing safety belt shall be punishable with a fine of `1,000.

Meanwhile, during a special drive conducted from September 14 to September 25, the Goa traffic police prosecuted 7,620 motorists for various violations. Police said that during the special drive, 701 cases of over-speeding, 101 cases of drunken driving, 2,271 cases of riding without helmet, 676 cases of driving without seat belt and 3,871 cases of dangerous parking were booked.

Police have appealed to all the road users, drivers and riders, particularly the young people, to drive/ride safely and responsibly and obey all the traffic rules.

The mandatory seat belt rule enforcement follows a fatal accident involving Cyrus Mistry, who wasn't wearing a seat belt when he died in a car crash. During a special drive from September 14-25, Goa traffic police prosecuted 7,620 motorists for various violations including speeding, drunk driving, riding without helmets, driving without seat belts, and dangerous parking.
